Award.AwardTitle: Novel Carbon Rich Organometallics based on iso-Triacetylene: Effects of Cross Conjugation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jonathan J. Wilker of the Department of Chemistry at Purdue University will explore the development of methods for the synthesis of carbon rich organometallics based on the combination of Ruthenium and sigma-iso-triacetylene ligands. The past efforts by the carbon rich organometallics community have focused on linear conjugated systems with oligo-yne, oligo-ene and oligo-phenyleneethynylene bridges. The incorporation of sigma-iso-triacetylene requires the development of novel synthetic chemistry. This project may expand our knowledge base about metal-alkynyl compounds. Furthermore, the ubiquitous cross-conjugation manifested by the iso-triacetylene bridge may result in novel physical properties that are absent in the linearly conjugated organometallics, especially the quantum interference effect.

The success of the proposed research will enrich the understanding of charge transfer processes in carbon-rich organometallic species and may lead to novel molecular wires and active materials for devices. In addition, this project will provide excellent training for undergraduate students and graduate students, broadening participation through the inclusion of the students from groups historically underrepresented in the sciences. It will also contribute to the existing Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program at Purdue University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

(NSF CHE 1057621)

 

Electron transfer processes are essential in biological, chemical and materials sciences. They play a critical role in metabolic processes and hence are indispensible to all living organisms. Also, electron transfer is key to all forms of energy conversion and storage processes, such as batteries and solar cells. Detailed understanding of electron transfer processes in chemical and biological systems has been an overarching goal for decades, and the knowledge gained has led to more efficient batteries and solar cells, and improved industrial catalysts.

Our project targets two significant aspects of electron transfer research: the distance dependence of the speed and the possibility to modulate the speed. For the former, we built Ru-based bimetallic compounds with a carbon chain bridge that is adjustable in lengths, and studied the electron transfer rate as a function of the lengths of linear carbon bridge. Separately, using a bimetallic Ru compound with a fixed length carbon bridge, we probed different chemical modifications to speed up or slow down electron transfer. As a more systematic way to control the speed of electron transfer, we looked into the carbon bridges that are slightly bent (cross conjugated), and investigated the methods to make mono- and bimetallic compounds containing such bent carbon bridges. This part of the project is still ongoing.

Our efforts in investigating bimetallic Ru-carbon bridge compounds have been well received by the scientific community. In addition, some of the compounds we made have been incorporated into memory devices with superb lifetimes. With a sustainable future in mind, our most recent effort on bent carbon bridges is based on earth abundant metals, such as iron, chromium, cobalt and nickel.  The research project has been a fertile training ground for both graduate and undergraduate students. Several graduate students worked on this project are currently working as either research chemists for companies like Merck and Nalco or assistant professors at various colleges/universities.  We are also working closely with the Purdue Science Express team in bringing modern instrumentation to high schools in the surrounding rural area, aiming to stimulate students' interest in sciences and STEM career.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2015
Modified by: Tong Ren
